Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Experimental and numerical studies of droplet formation and cell encapsulation in micro-channels for high-throughput electrical measurements

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of the research is to investigate and promote the use of pico-liter scale droplets for encapsulation and monitoring of bacterial growth, mammalian cell growth, and PCR reactions. The approach is to ascertain both experimentally and numerically, the device design, mechanisms of encapsulation, and biological reactions inside the droplets. The research is expected to result in increased understanding of the fundamental mechanisms as well as realization of practical devices for point-of-care diagnostics and screening applications.
The intellectual merits of the proposed work include the development of novel numerical techniques for simulation of the cell encapsulation process, obtaining fundamental insight into the process of cell encapsulation in the droplets of cell media or buffer, examining the effect of ionic liquid medium on the cells, a systematic experiment and simulation approach to design the devices for optical capture, and whether single cell reactions can be interrogated inside these droplets.
The broader impact of the proposed work is that a further understanding of the mechanism of cell encapsulation process in micro-channels will directly guide the use of droplets as reaction vessels for cells and molecules in biochemical applications. Thus, the proposed study can serves as generic platform that allows the biological activities to be monitored in real time using electrical means resulting in compact devices. The devices would be used to demonstrate fundamentals of microfluidics and bioassays to high school students in science fairs at OSU and as part of a microfluidic module in a 2 week long summer school at UIUC.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Micro-fluidic systems generating liquid droplets in an outer immiscible liquid have recently received considerable attention due to their biological and chemical application implication. Liquid droplets are widely used as reactors for the chemical manipulation of cells and the ability to monitor the behavior of single or very few cells is important to the understanding of the fundamental characteristics of the cell growth. The droplet formation and the cell encapsulation are complex multi-scale, fluid-structure and cell deformation coupled problem. The ability to predict the dynamics of these two processes numerically is critical to facilitate the design and development of effective micro-fluidic systems. In this study, the state-of-the-art numerical techniques are developed to simulate the droplet formation as well as the cell encapsulation phenomenon in micro-T-junctions. T-junctions are chosen in the simulations because of their ease in droplet-size controllability and periodicity of drop formation, and also the design simplicity. The numerical method developed is based on the multi-component lattice Boltzmann method and the immersed boundary method. Simulations demonstrate that the code has the capacity to reproduce the droplet formation and cell encapsulation processes. The droplet formation is identified to have three flow regimes including squeezing, dripping and jetting schemes, which are comparing well with available data in the literature. In the simulations of cell encapsulation, it is found that cells experience remarkable three-dimensional rotation including tank-treading motion, which is important to understand how cells deform and get damaged. Hence, the established numerical method will be helpful in facilitating the design and development of new micro-fluidic systems for biological and chemical applications.
